children.text: The Python language has a ton of pre-built functions, but most aren't included in the built-in package (the one available by default). Most of the functions are organized into separate
To use a function from a library, you must
the library. This makes it possible to access the functions and variables in that collection. You can do this with the
All the Python libraries have documentation online that describes which functions are available and what they do. Find it by searching
/. It's better to check the documentation as needed than to try to memorize library functions.
For example, we can import the math library to add more mathematical capabilities. Note that we must put math. in front of
each function or variable name we use, to specify it came from that library.
math.ceil(6.5) # ceiling of a float number
math.log(64, 2) # finds the log of 64 with base 2
Importing libraries lets us get more creative with programming. For example, the
library lets us generate random numbers, which can help produce novel behavior.
random.randint(1, 10) # picks a random int between 1-10 inclusive
random.random() # picks a random float between 0-1
Finally, to get really creative, we can produce graphics with programming! We'll do this with the
library, which makes it possible to draw shapes on a separate screen.
We need to run some code before and after our graphics code to make it work.
is the thing on the window where we can draw shapes. The
line will tell the window to stay open until we press the X button.
Coordinates on the Canvas Grow Down-Right
created by the starter code is the thing we'll draw graphics on. It's a two-dimensional grid of pixels. This grid has a pre-set
; the number of pixels from left to right and the number of pixels from top to bottom.
We can refer to pixels on the canvas by their (x, y) coordinates. However, these coordinates are different from coordinates on mathematical graphs – the origin starts at the
To draw a rectangle, use the function canvas.create_rectangle. This function takes four required arguments: the x and y coordinates of
the left-top corner, and the x and y coordinates of the right-bottom corner. The rectangle will then be drawn between those two points.
With the basic parameters, we can only draw outlines of shapes. By adding
, we can change the properties of these shapes.

A keyword argument is an argument that is associated with a specific name instead of a position in the function call. We can put keyword arguments in any order we like as long as they occur after the main arguments.
, which is why we don't need to include them in every graphics call. To change that default value, include the keyword, followed by
, followed by the new value in the function call.
the argument can be used to give a rectangle a color. It uses a string (the name of the color) to change the color of the shape.
Note that when we draw shapes on top of each other, the one on top is the
Graphics – Side Effects and Returned Values

When the rectangle is drawn on the canvas, we can't use it in future computations. That's a side effect. The graphics function call also returns something – an integer ID associated with the drawn shape. We won't use that value in this class.
You can draw a lot more than just rectangles with Tkinter graphics!
